answers.answer: Kidney disease, Diabetes, Hyperadrenocorticism, or even a severe urinary tract infection could cause what you are describing.  Please take a  fresh urine sample to your vet, if possible and have your cat's bloodwork checked, as well as having an exam.

question: 2 kitty litter boxes for one cat - completely cleaned and filled both boxes with fresh litter 4 days ago - they are now completely saturated with liquid - the entire box is wet and looks like someone poured a gallon of water into it.  It doesn't smell like urine - stinks more and no amonia smell.  This started about 2 weeks ago and the amount of liquid is unbelievable. I have used the same kitty litter for years and I have been able to clean weekly by just removing a small portion of the litter.  Now I have to dump the entire box and wash and fill with fresh litter about every 4 days. The cat is acting normal, eating normally and doesn't appear to be in any distress of pain. What could cause such a drastic increase in liquid output?
title: excessive urination
